I believe the python packaging in this repo is used by RDO to "build" this package into an RPM from a tarball.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-04-29 20:05:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

are you sure? We removed on a couple of ansible repos setup.py already...'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-04-29 20:06:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

then let me cleanup the mess here ;)'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-04-29 20:15:47.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 7973, 'date': '2020-04-29 20:16:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm still working on getting the RDO spec for this repo fleshed out, but AFAIK that's how ansible-role rpms get made.  Or at least that's how we package the other barbican related ansible roles like ansible-role-atos-hsm:

https://review.rdoproject.org/cgit/openstack/ansible-role-atos-hsm-distgit/tree/ansible-role-atos-hsm.spec#n40"}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2020-04-29 20:18:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

might be different for ansible-roles then.

Anyhow, the change I just pushed should be file now and not conflict
with your spec file.'}, {'account_id': 7973, 'date': '2020-04-29 20:24:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 9914, 'date': '2020-05-11 18:24:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Small cleanups

setup.cfg: Remove obsolete sections.

tox.ini: Fix typo, set basepython as well.

Change-Id: I44105c3d472493b1821a37e2c2dbe9aff9828cbb

If a stack has no tags we want to be able to return an empty list []

Change-Id: I2f31e6b1f59149370e57e5cb43984476e4a1902c
Task: 37005

commit_message:
Allow empty list of tags instead of None

If a stack has no tags we want to be able to return an empty list []
instead of None.

Change-Id: I2f31e6b1f59149370e57e5cb43984476e4a1902c
Task: 37005

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-11 15:14:54.000000000', 'message': 'Fluentd: Render Config as Template

This change updates the fluentd configmap-etc to render
.Values.conf.fluentd.template as a template, allowing for greater
flexibility in configuration.

Change-Id: I8809767c679c377e319ecc53960c55ae18e1b558
'}]
commit_message:
Fluentd: Render Config as Template

This change updates the fluentd configmap-etc to render
.Values.conf.fluentd.template as a template, allowing for greater
flexibility in configuration.

Change-Id: I8809767c679c377e319ecc53960c55ae18e1b558

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-08 13:31:23.000000000', 'message': "[ovn]: Fix l3_plugin.add_router_interface to comply with RouterPluginBase

OVNL3RouterPlugin inherits from L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin, which inherits
from neutron.extensions.l3.RouterPluginBase

As maintenance task expects OVNL3RouterPlugin to behave as
RouterPluginBase, the add_router_interface should have the signature:

  add_router_interface(self, context, router_id, interface_info)

Note: With this change, the default behavior of OVNL3RouterPlugin's
_add_neutron_router_interface becomes idem-potent: multiple calls to add
the same interface will not fail. Because of that, the unit test
test_router_add_interface_dup_port no longer makes sense and is being
removed.

Closes-Bug: #1876148
Change-Id: I8010113b4d8c66ecbccf3126f322a8836d92e7ba
Signed-off-by: Flavio Fernandes <flaviof@redhat.com>
"}]
commit_message:
[ovn]: Fix l3_plugin.add_router_interface to comply with RouterPluginBase

OVNL3RouterPlugin inherits from L3_NAT_dbonly_mixin, which inherits
from neutron.extensions.l3.RouterPluginBase

As maintenance task expects OVNL3RouterPlugin to behave as
RouterPluginBase, the add_router_interface should have the signature:

  add_router_interface(self, context, router_id, interface_info)

Note: With this change, the default behavior of OVNL3RouterPlugin's
_add_neutron_router_interface becomes idem-potent: multiple calls to add
the same interface will not fail. Because of that, the unit test
test_router_add_interface_dup_port no longer makes sense and is being
removed.

Closes-Bug: #1876148
Change-Id: I8010113b4d8c66ecbccf3126f322a8836d92e7ba
Signed-off-by: Flavio Fernandes <flaviof@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Strip self from incoming glance properties

We do this in list, but we should really also do it in
translate response - because seriously this can never work.

Change-Id: Ic97499b9fe1b563049da59899c34dbd810fe1509

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-24 15:09:16.000000000', 'message': "Add config option for neutron client retries

Nova can occasionally fail to carry out server actions which require
calls to neutron API if haproxy happens to close a connection after
idle time if an incoming request attempts to re-use the connection
while it is being torn down.

In order to be more resilient to this scenario, we can add a config
option for neutron client to retry requests, similar to our existing
CONF.cinder.http_retries and CONF.glance.num_retries options.

Because we create our neutron client [1] using a keystoneauth1 session
[2], we can set the 'connect_retries' keyword argument to let
keystoneauth1 handle connection retries.

Closes-Bug: #1866937

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/57459c3429ce62975cebd0cd70936785bdf2f3a4/nova/network/neutron.py#L226-L237
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/keystoneauth/latest/api/keystoneauth1.session.html#keystoneauth1.session.Session

Change-Id: Ifb3afb13aff7e103c2e80ade817d0e63b624604a
(cherry picked from commit 0e34ed9733e3f23d162e3e428795807386abf1cb)
(cherry picked from commit 71971c206292232fff389dedbf412d780f0a557a)
(cherry picked from commit a96e7ab83066bee0a13a54070aab988396bae320)
"}]
commit_message:
Add config option for neutron client retries

Nova can occasionally fail to carry out server actions which require
calls to neutron API if haproxy happens to close a connection after
idle time if an incoming request attempts to re-use the connection
while it is being torn down.

In order to be more resilient to this scenario, we can add a config
option for neutron client to retry requests, similar to our existing
CONF.cinder.http_retries and CONF.glance.num_retries options.

Because we create our neutron client [1] using a keystoneauth1 session
[2], we can set the 'connect_retries' keyword argument to let
keystoneauth1 handle connection retries.

Closes-Bug: #1866937

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/57459c3429ce62975cebd0cd70936785bdf2f3a4/nova/network/neutron.py#L226-L237
[2] https://docs.openstack.org/keystoneauth/latest/api/keystoneauth1.session.html#keystoneauth1.session.Session

Change-Id: Ifb3afb13aff7e103c2e80ade817d0e63b624604a
(cherry picked from commit 0e34ed9733e3f23d162e3e428795807386abf1cb)
(cherry picked from commit 71971c206292232fff389dedbf412d780f0a557a)
(cherry picked from commit a96e7ab83066bee0a13a54070aab988396bae320)

commit_message:
Correct image lookup during server rebuild

The switch to using glance from the SDK accidentally used get_image
directly during a server rebuild, when it should have used find_image to
match existing functionality.

Bug introduced in: I36f292fb70c98f6e558f58be55d533d979c47ca7

Change-Id: I2005bd40a1bd6719670c7f7854316b4f9801b140
Story: 2007620
Task: 39643

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-04-24 23:22:27.000000000', 'message': "Lowercase ironic driver hash ring and ignore case in cache

Recently we had a customer case where attempts to add new ironic nodes
to an existing undercloud resulted in half of the nodes failing to be
detected and added to nova. Ironic API returned all of the newly added
nodes when called by the driver, but half of the nodes were not
returned to the compute manager by the driver.

There was only one nova-compute service managing all of the ironic
nodes of the all-in-one typical undercloud deployment.

After days of investigation and examination of a database dump from the
customer, we noticed that at some point the customer had changed the
hostname of the machine from something containing uppercase letters to
the same name but all lowercase. The nova-compute service record had
the mixed case name and the CONF.host (socket.gethostname()) had the
lowercase name.

The hash ring logic adds all of the nova-compute service hostnames plus
CONF.host to hash ring, then the ironic driver reports only the nodes
it owns by retrieving a service hostname from the ring based on a hash
of each ironic node UUID.

Because of the machine hostname change, the hash ring contained, for
example: {'MachineHostName', 'machinehostname'} when it should have
contained only one hostname. And because the hash ring contained two
hostnames, the driver was able to retrieve only half of the nodes as
nodes that it owned. So half of the new nodes were excluded and not
added as new compute nodes.

This adds lowercasing of hosts that are added to the hash ring and
ignores case when comparing the CONF.host to the hash ring members
to avoid unnecessary pain and confusion for users that make hostname
changes that are otherwise functionally harmless.

This also adds logging of the set of hash ring members at level DEBUG
to help enable easier debugging of hash ring related situations.

Closes-Bug: #1866380

commit_message:
Lowercase ironic driver hash ring and ignore case in cache

Recently we had a customer case where attempts to add new ironic nodes
to an existing undercloud resulted in half of the nodes failing to be
detected and added to nova. Ironic API returned all of the newly added
nodes when called by the driver, but half of the nodes were not
returned to the compute manager by the driver.

There was only one nova-compute service managing all of the ironic
nodes of the all-in-one typical undercloud deployment.

After days of investigation and examination of a database dump from the
customer, we noticed that at some point the customer had changed the
hostname of the machine from something containing uppercase letters to
the same name but all lowercase. The nova-compute service record had
the mixed case name and the CONF.host (socket.gethostname()) had the
lowercase name.

The hash ring logic adds all of the nova-compute service hostnames plus
CONF.host to hash ring, then the ironic driver reports only the nodes
it owns by retrieving a service hostname from the ring based on a hash
of each ironic node UUID.

Because of the machine hostname change, the hash ring contained, for
example: {'MachineHostName', 'machinehostname'} when it should have
contained only one hostname. And because the hash ring contained two
hostnames, the driver was able to retrieve only half of the nodes as
nodes that it owned. So half of the new nodes were excluded and not
added as new compute nodes.

This adds lowercasing of hosts that are added to the hash ring and
ignores case when comparing the CONF.host to the hash ring members
to avoid unnecessary pain and confusion for users that make hostname
changes that are otherwise functionally harmless.

This also adds logging of the set of hash ring members at level DEBUG
to help enable easier debugging of hash ring related situations.

Closes-Bug: #1866380

Change-Id: I617fd59de327de05a198f12b75a381f21945afb0
(cherry picked from commit 7145100ee4e732caa532d614e2149ef2a545287a)
(cherry picked from commit 588b0484bf6f5fe41514f1428aeaf5613635e35a)
(cherry picked from commit 8f8667a8dd0e453eaef8f75a3fff25db62d4cc17)
(cherry picked from commit 019e3da75bc6fb171b32a012ce339075fe690ca7)

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-01 14:56:07.000000000', 'message': 'Include only required fields in ironic node cache

The ironic virt driver maintains a cache of ironic nodes to avoid
continually polling the ironic API.  Code paths requiring a specific
node use a limited set of fields, _NODE_FIELDS, when querying the
ironic API for the node. This reduces the memory footprint required by
the cache, and the network traffic required to populate it. However,
in most cases the cache is populated using a detailed node list
operation in _refresh_cache(), which includes all node fields.

This change specifies _NODE_FIELDS in the node list operation in
_refresh_cache().

We also modify the unit tests to use fake node objects that are
representative of the nodes in the cache.

Change-Id: Id96e7e513f469b87992ddae1431cce714e91ed16
Related-Bug: #1746209
(cherry picked from commit 8bbad196a7f6a6e2ea093aeee87dfde2154c9358)
'}]
commit_message:
Include only required fields in ironic node cache

The ironic virt driver maintains a cache of ironic nodes to avoid
continually polling the ironic API.  Code paths requiring a specific
node use a limited set of fields, _NODE_FIELDS, when querying the
ironic API for the node. This reduces the memory footprint required by
the cache, and the network traffic required to populate it. However,
in most cases the cache is populated using a detailed node list
operation in _refresh_cache(), which includes all node fields.

This change specifies _NODE_FIELDS in the node list operation in
_refresh_cache().

We also modify the unit tests to use fake node objects that are
representative of the nodes in the cache.

Change-Id: Id96e7e513f469b87992ddae1431cce714e91ed16
Related-Bug: #1746209
(cherry picked from commit 8bbad196a7f6a6e2ea093aeee87dfde2154c9358)

commit_message:
rbd: Correct local_attach disconnect test and showmapped arguments

Id507109df80391699074773f4787f74507c4b882 introduced the showmapped
command when attempting to disconnect locally attached rbd volumes.
Unfortunately at the time the test changes incorrectly attempted to
assert the commands made by using has_calls instead of the valid
assert_has_calls method.

This change now corrects this, ensures _get_rbd_args is called to
populate all of the required arguments for the showmapped command and
finally corrects the name stored within the fake showmapped output in
the test.

Change-Id: I7e761828b3799cef720e15ca7896e8e8d6f98182

Adding --ignore-installed

Adding ignore-installed fix it

commit_message:
Add py38 package metadata

Now that we are running the Victoria tests that include a
voting py38, we can now add the Python 3.8 metadata to the
package information to reflect that support.

Change-Id: I4600211320beeb2b81e620bcce8545cb60b0a3ad
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Refresh OVN Appendix

Refresh content to reflect OVN as preferred default for reference
implementation.

Move links to the bottom of the page as stated in the style guide.

Add detailed feature description for DPDK, SR-IOV and hardware offload.

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-06 14:25:25.000000000', 'message': 'UTC times can be confusing, explain times better

If real time equivalents for the time slots are provided, add
a link to timeanddate.com corresponding to the time, and display
browser local time equivalent for the time displayed.

Also make sure that the day tab corresponds to the UTC day (until
01 UTC the next day) whatever your timezone is.

Change-Id: I7847e0ac68fc6fcd176d40cc94d4e21c3c6e03e0
'}]
commit_message:
UTC times can be confusing, explain times better

If real time equivalents for the time slots are provided, add
a link to timeanddate.com corresponding to the time, and display
browser local time equivalent for the time displayed.

Also make sure that the day tab corresponds to the UTC day (until
01 UTC the next day) whatever your timezone is.

Change-Id: I7847e0ac68fc6fcd176d40cc94d4e21c3c6e03e0

commit_message:
Enable metrics qdr to use public VIP

Backport of ec0248d3d84c0a6b176f13e7d2b89cfca55698a8

This patch adds HAProxy configuration for MetricsQdr service, so that
QDRs running on controller nodes in interior mode can be accessed
by external clients (such as CloudForms)

Depends-On: I195dbf70f490984cedb32d48fe09f4562cbf94fa
Change-Id: I7a7b5e79a9bdbc448fc862394c136d6792141b15
Signed-off-by: Ryan McCabe <rmccabe@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Enable external public endpoint for MetricsQdr

Backport of 5ea84f71ea124191ae0cfa04253cc264210eac9b

This patch adds public endpoint for MetricsQdr and makes the service
to listen on it when deployed on controller nodes (when enabled interio
mode on controllers)

Depends-On: I9ede734f296ba52e86977904d3e5e6ac3bf9c410
Change-Id: I3566496cbd886a18c29345484d6f6c6c75df9db4

commit_message:
Use public network for external interface

Backport of 553ede19454e470312f12a2bc85f0b67e7128273

This patch adds possibility for metrics' QDR to listen on public network
for external connections (from CloudForms for example).

Change-Id: I9ede734f296ba52e86977904d3e5e6ac3bf9c410
Signed-off-by: Ryan McCabe <rmccabe@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Docs: Configure firewall to allow testing of baremetal

Due to Docker's iptables configuration, it is now necessary to modify
iptables in order to test bare metal provisioning using Tenks. Update
the development instructions accordingly.

Change-Id: I598066ff2574ff572a88d351e3b4d734a824ae93
(cherry picked from commit b02cdf59fbeb2ef8f8042cef3908781e70708591)

Docs: Configure firewall to allow testing of baremetal

Due to Docker's iptables configuration, it is now necessary to modify
iptables in order to test bare metal provisioning using Tenks. Update
the development instructions accordingly.

commit_message:
Support for room and track URLs

Allow to associate a URL to a room, for example a link to a video
conference room. Tracks assigned to this room will automatically inherit
the link. The link for a given track can be overridden using the "url"
command.

This allows organizers to provide video links for each room, while still
enabling teams to link to whatever they end up really using.

Change-Id: I633eb83c579e4093ae769bcd053e4d2ec2fe4bc3

commit_message:
Switch to Victoria tests

This repo has been using train tests and thus was missed by the bot to
update from ussuri to victoria, update manually.

See also the PTI in governance [1].

[1]: https://governance.openstack.org/tc/reference/project-testing-interface.html

subprocess.check_output to capture the data from the ping cmd.

commit_message:
Add debug output for libvirt ping checks

This patch adds some extra debug options to the ping check. It writes
the STDOUT of ping subprocess to a temporary file which can be logged in
the debug log level.

Change-Id: Ife9a1d409a8326fb9ff07b1b04508cd11f899d10

[{'created': '2020-02-05 10:50:35.000000000', 'message': 'More verbose logs for cluster ops

Most of the times issues with cluster update/upgrade/resize can be
identified just by looking at the parameters sent to Heat. This patch
changes the existing log messages for cluster update and resize to info
from debug. Adds a log message for cluster upgrade.

Change-Id: Ibac5e105885b6e7042e88dea31cfeafe42a401ab
'}, {'created': '2020-05-07 08:46:32.000000000', 'message': 'More verbose logs for cluster ops

Most of the times issues with cluster update/upgrade/resize can be
identified just by looking at the parameters sent to Heat. This patch

commit_message:
More verbose logs for cluster ops

Most of the times issues with cluster update/upgrade/resize can be
identified just by looking at the parameters sent to Heat. This patch
changes the existing log messages for cluster update and resize to info
from debug. Adds a log message for cluster upgrade.

story: #2007636
task: #39689
Change-Id: Ibac5e105885b6e7042e88dea31cfeafe42a401ab

commit_message:
Fixes Gnocchi & external Ceph integration

The removal of Kolla Ceph deploy [1] broke gnocchi & external Ceph
integration - the variable gnocchi_pool_name is referenced in the config
template, but should now be ceph_gnocchi_pool_name.

This change fixes the issue.

Reported by Nick Wilson.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/704309/12/ansible/roles/gnocchi/defaults/main.yml

Change-Id: I7089781c0c4d7bce8a44cb8b1fca847dd0b7efd1
Closes-Bug: #1877974

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-11 11:59:42.000000000', 'message': 'Let default install helper do its job

Change I80809dbe0ae43a87986b33c902e0eb53563cb90d added a required
deb package to be installed by the charm.

Before that the only installation done was through the snap layer
and the charm updated the status and set the ``charm.installed``
to have the status set correctly.

Remove this code as this now is at odds with the requirement of
having a deb installed before charm operation.

Closes-Bug: #1877972
Change-Id: Iee82f7ff066e81787bb658bca3dfce4087ab4e00
'}]
commit_message:
Let default install helper do its job

Change I80809dbe0ae43a87986b33c902e0eb53563cb90d added a required
deb package to be installed by the charm.

Before that the only installation done was through the snap layer
and the charm updated the status and set the ``charm.installed``
to have the status set correctly.

Remove this code as this now is at odds with the requirement of
having a deb installed before charm operation.

Closes-Bug: #1877972
Change-Id: Iee82f7ff066e81787bb658bca3dfce4087ab4e00

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-11 08:59:01.000000000', 'message': "Make nova perms consistent between applications

Nova cells support introduced a slight regression that triggers
odd behaviour when we tried switching to Apache (httpd) [1].
Bootstrap no longer applied permissions recursively to all log
files, creating a discrepancy between normal and bootstrap runs
and also Nova and other services such as Cinder (regarding
bootstrap logging).

This patch fixes it.

Backport to Train.

Not creating reno nor a bug record because it does not affect
any current standard usage in any currently known way.

Note this only really hides (standardizes?) the global issue that
we don't control file permissions on newly created files too well.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/724793

Change-Id: I35e9924ccede5edd2e1307043379aba944725143
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/724793
(cherry picked from commit 93c9ad892cb26ec44fccb69a3cf34da479274da4)
"}]
commit_message:
Make nova perms consistent between applications

Nova cells support introduced a slight regression that triggers
odd behaviour when we tried switching to Apache (httpd) [1].
Bootstrap no longer applied permissions recursively to all log
files, creating a discrepancy between normal and bootstrap runs
and also Nova and other services such as Cinder (regarding
bootstrap logging).

This patch fixes it.

Backport to Train.

Not creating reno nor a bug record because it does not affect
any current standard usage in any currently known way.

Note this only really hides (standardizes?) the global issue that
we don't control file permissions on newly created files too well.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/724793

Change-Id: I35e9924ccede5edd2e1307043379aba944725143
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/724793
(cherry picked from commit 93c9ad892cb26ec44fccb69a3cf34da479274da4)

commit_message:
Use more octavia-lib constants

Octavia has a pretty extensive definition of constants,
start using them where possible.  Had to tweak a lot of
lines due to wrapping, but functionally nothing should
have changed.

Removed some extra parens where found and other misc
cleanups.

Also bumped neutron-lib to >= 2.1.0 since that is py3-only.

Change-Id: If400730cb759130192966bacf3c6edb9faa18899

commit_message:
migration: Replace paunch with podman and ip commands

The patch removes paunch and cleans network namespaces by iterating over
namespaces belonging to Neutron agents. It also clears side-car
containers spawned by Neutron using podman command.

Change-Id: I017e7b3c3674e065a523eff5ebbea352f619f45e
(cherry-picked from I017e7b3c3674e065a523eff5ebbea352f619f45e)

commit_message:
Make tripleo-ci-centos-7-containerized-undercloud-upgrades non-voting

This job is failing because of podman update issues. Will be make
it voting once podman issue will be fixed.

Related-Bug: #1876893
Change-Id: Iaf5cdb0b7de3c279e22f0c86e103cac6dec9ceb1
Signed-off-by: Amol Kahat <amolkahat@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fixes instance resizing/migration when swap volume is on lvm

In an environment, where on compute nodes the swap devices
are provided via local lvm currently instance resizing and instance
migration fail. The suggested modification provides an appropriate
mechanism

1) recognizing those swap devices correctly
2) not trying to copy the swap device via scp but delete it on
   the source node and recreate it on the target node

Closes Bug: #1755266

Change-Id: I3b4d5c64ce1a43b234c290fc409398ab677f533d

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

Note we do have a nova-lvm integration job, I just wonder if it's not running any resize tests that involve a swap disk (would have to check in Tempest)."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-06-03 16:41:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

Thanks for digging into a bug in the least loved amongst the unloved imagebackends :)

In general, we still aren't going to be able to say that cold migration/resize of LVM backed instances is 'supported', because we'll still fail if the flavor has ephemeral disks. However, for the special case where there's just a swap disk, which we don't copy anyway, we should be able to skirt round the problem in the way you describe here.

As noted below, I think the cleanup issue is entirely separate. I don't think you need that fix to fix the cold migration issue, so you'd be well advised to separate it out. Apart from anything, as you've probably noticed you'll just be increasing the number of tests you need to add/fix."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-06-03 16:50:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

commit_message:
Fixes instance resizing/migration when swap volume is on lvm

In an environment, where on compute nodes the swap devices
are provided via local lvm currently instance resizing and instance
migration fail. The suggested modification provides an appropriate
mechanism

1) recognizing those swap devices correctly
2) not trying to copy the swap device via scp but delete it on
   the source node and recreate it on the target node

Closes Bug: #1755266

Change-Id: I57b708ec3016901df52d9b57e02d9ed1d0ed3f57

Revert "Deprecate the vmwareapi driver"

VMWARE CI is back to work.

This reverts commit d98d72828505d250698fcab7cd310820b3a52f7a.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/684375/3 : SUCCESS in 2h 26m 38s'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-10-01 08:25:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Summarizing the IRC discussion[*] between Eric Fried, MattR, Dan Smith and myself from 26-Sep-2019:

* Eric suggests: "If you wanted to be super safe, you could make a [workaround] conf opt, defaulting to "prefer", to allow consumers to revert to "strict" if they want.  Deprecate it immediately (assuming we don't want to continue to allow it) and remove it in U."  (Eric later writes:  "I'm not totally convinced this should be a [workaround] in the first place -- perhaps it should be an actual conf opt.")

* MattR: "+1 on the workarounds idea, that also allows people to opt out if they dont' have the kernel fix."

* Dan Smith chimed in on tangential, but the general topic of workarounds: "I always wanted the workarounds to be booleans that all default to False, opting into different behavior, not multi-value tunables".  Setting some regular-looking conf tunable to some value is less like a workaround and more like ... config".  But Eric makes a good point of: "(IMO) it's an unnecessary extra step making them understand how True/False maps to "prefer"/"strict""


[*] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-09-26.log.html#t2019-09-26T13:55:41'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-10-01 19:09:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Summarizing the IRC discussion

So we're still waiting for you to decide what to do here, right?

I don't really care if you make it a [workaround] or a regular conf opt (where? [compute]? [libvirt]?).

Or is this you having decided to do neither?"}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-10-03 09:14:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

I'm still not sure if we should be doing this rather than encouraging people to update their kernel (and pressure their distro vendor if they haven't backported the fix yet). If we were going to do this, I'd like it to be configurable on a per-instance basis via flavor extra specs or something, but that's a different issue unrelated to this. The decision would pretty much be based on how long standing this issue is"}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-10-07 12:24:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

- check-nova-master http://extbasicopstackcilog01.podc.sl.edst.ibm.com/test_logs/jenkins-check-nova-master-37890 : FAILURE in 1h 18m 20s'}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2020-01-16 14:30:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+1

@Stephen update the kernel (reboot) would be great but it disrupts the service especially in large deployments. I tested this patch and it solves it.'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-01-16 14:36:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-2'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-01-16 14:38:08.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > I'm still not sure if we should be doing this rather than
 > encouraging people to update their kernel (and pressure their
 > distro vendor if they haven't backported the fix yet). If we were
 > going to do this, I'd like it to be configurable on a per-instance
 > basis via flavor extra specs or something, but that's a different
 > issue unrelated to this. The decision would pretty much be based on
 > how long standing this issue is

-2 because that ^"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2020-01-16 14:57:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

even though i originally suggested this im not comfortable with it being applied to all numa vms.

based on the fact that belmiro has tested it i would be ok with it as a workaroud config option as long as we default to strict and
note that this option might be remvoed in the future.

if we update the patch to that effect then ill be +1 on it.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2020-01-16 15:33:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > I'm still not sure if we should be doing this rather than
 > encouraging people to update their kernel (and pressure their
 > distro vendor if they haven't backported the fix yet). If we were
 > going to do this, I'd like it to be configurable on a per-instance
 > basis via flavor extra specs or something, but that's a different
 > issue unrelated to this. The decision would pretty much be based on
 > how long standing this issue is

On how long the issue has been around:  it is a latent issue (also confirmed with the KVM maintainer).

In general, I'm a strong proponent to make distribution vendors to backport such fixes (and most _would_ do).  But as Belmiro noted on #openstack-nova IRC channel, not all deployments can have the luxury for a kernel reboot; so in that light, we may have to go the  [workarounds] route."}, {'account_id': 2033, 'date': '2020-03-23 11:03:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I needed to change our compute_nodes from "strict" to "preferred"! I just hit the following issue when starting an instance that uses more than one NUMA node.
(libvirtError: internal error: Process exited prior to exec: libvirt:  error : internal error: NUMA memory tuning in 'preferred' mode only supports single node)
If this option is not configurable it should continue to default to "strict".'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2020-05-11 13:37:55.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-09-24 15:13:38.000000000', 'message': 'libvirt: Use the "memory" mode 'preferred' for a guest NUMA node

Problem
-------

Currently Nova defaults to the 'strict' mode when allocating memory for
a guest on a NUMA node:

    <numatune>
       <memory mode="strict" nodeset="1-4,^3"/>
         ...
    <numatune>

And if your host does not have a "DMA32" region (it is one of the
'zones' into which the kernel divides the system memory) for that NUMA
node, then instance launch fails with:

    qemu-kvm: kvm_init_vcpu failed: Cannot allocate memory

(NB: The issue here is not main memory allocation - "oh, your host is
just out of memory"; it's a specific problem in context of NUMA.)

Solution
--------

Use the mode 'preferred', instead of 'strict', when allocating memory
for the QEMU process (Nova instance).  Where, 'preferred' just means
"disable NUMA affinity", and so the request is turned to a "hint", i.e.
"if possible, allocate from the NUMA node; otherwise, don't."

(Thanks, Sean Mooney for the above explanation.)

References
----------

(1) Here is a similar report from LKML on the same error:

      https://lkml.org/lkml/2018/7/24/152 -- VM boot failure on nodes
      not having DMA32 zone

    The above is fixed in kernel 4.19 or above:

      ee6268ba3a68 (KVM: x86: Skip pae_root shadow allocation if tdp
      enabled, 2018-07-25)

(2) Let me cite the Doc Text from this[*] (fixed) libvirt bug from 2015:

      Cause: For domains with <numatune><memory mode='strict'
      nodeset='X'/> libvirt strictly prohibited qemu/kvm from allocating
      memory from NUMA nodes outside the nodeset X.

      Consequence: When qemu initializes, kvm needs to allocate some
      memory from the DMA32 zone.  If that zone was present only on a
      NUMA node outside that X, the allocation failed and the domain
      couldn't start.

      [...]

    And Nova is using 'strict' mode for the "memory" element.

[*] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1010885#c2 --
    kvm_init_vcpu failed: Cannot allocate memory in NUMA

Change-Id: I2047f935bdffbc72b066d905b0766bfb1f3cc57a
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
Thanks: Sean Mooney <work@seanmooney.info>

"disable NUMA affinity", and so the request is turned to a "hint", i.e.

(Thanks, Sean Mooney for the above explanation.)

References

      https://lkml.org/lkml/2018/7/24/152 -- VM boot failure on nodes
      not having DMA32 zone

      ee6268ba3a68 (KVM: x86: Skip pae_root shadow allocation if tdp

      memory from the DMA32 zone.  If that zone was present only on a

      [...]

    And Nova is using 'strict' mode for the "memory" element.

Problem
-------

Currently Nova defaults to the 'strict' mode when allocating memory for
a guest on a NUMA node:

    <numatune>
       <memory mode="strict" nodeset="1-4,^3"/>
         ...
    <numatune>

And if your host does not have a "DMA32" region (it is one of the
'zones' into which the kernel divides the system memory) for that NUMA
node, then instance launch fails with:

    qemu-kvm: kvm_init_vcpu failed: Cannot allocate memory

(NB: The issue here is not the main memory allocation -- "oh, your host
simply does not have enough memory"; it's a specific problem in context
of NUMA.)

Solution
--------

Ideally, users are recommended to run a Linux kernel with the fix
mentioned in the first reference below.  The mode 'preferred', instead
of 'strict', when allocating memory for the QEMU process (Nova
instance).  Where, 'preferred' means: disable NUMA affinity and so the
request is turned to a "hint", i.e. "if possible, allocate from the
given NUMA node; otherwise, fallback to other nodes".

References
----------

(1) A report on LKML for the same problem:

      https://lkml.org/lkml/2018/7/24/152 -- VM boot failure on nodes
      not having DMA32 zone

    ... which resulted in the following patch, available in kernel 4.19
    or higher (or in a distribution kernel with the patch backported):

      ee6268ba3a68 (KVM: x86: Skip pae_root shadow allocation if tdp
      enabled, 2018-07-25)

(2) A similar report on 'openstack-discuss' list:

      http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-September/009770.html
      -- "issues creating a second vm with numa affinity"

(3) And the following libvirt commits (and an old, related, libvirt bug):

      - https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1010885#c2
        -- "kvm_init_vcpu failed: Cannot allocate memory in NUMA"

      - https://libvirt.org/git/?p=libvirt.git;a=commit;h=0eaa4716e1
        -- "qemu: Set up EMULATOR thread and cpuset.mems before
        exec()-ing qemu")

      - https://libvirt.org/git/?p=libvirt.git;a=commit;h=7e72ac7878
        -- "qemu: leave restricting cpuset.mems after initialization"

Change-Id: I2047f935bdffbc72b066d905b0766bfb1f3cc57a
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
Thanks: Sean Mooney <work@seanmooney.info>
'}]
commit_message:
libvirt: Use the `preferred` memory allocation mode for NUMA

Problem
-------

Currently Nova defaults to the 'strict' mode when allocating memory for
a guest on a NUMA node:

    <numatune>
       <memory mode="strict" nodeset="1-4,^3"/>
         ...
    <numatune>

And if your host does not have a "DMA32" region (it is one of the
'zones' into which the kernel divides the system memory) for that NUMA
node, then instance launch fails with:

    qemu-kvm: kvm_init_vcpu failed: Cannot allocate memory

(NB: The issue here is not the main memory allocation -- "oh, your host
simply does not have enough memory"; it's a specific problem in context
of NUMA.)

Solution
--------

Ideally, users are recommended to run a Linux kernel with the fix
mentioned in the first reference below.  The mode 'preferred', instead
of 'strict', when allocating memory for the QEMU process (Nova
instance).  Where, 'preferred' means: disable NUMA affinity and so the
request is turned to a "hint", i.e. "if possible, allocate from the
given NUMA node; otherwise, fallback to other nodes".

References
----------

(1) A report on LKML for the same problem:

      https://lkml.org/lkml/2018/7/24/152 -- VM boot failure on nodes
      not having DMA32 zone

    ... which resulted in the following patch, available in kernel 4.19
    or higher (or in a distribution kernel with the patch backported):

      ee6268ba3a68 (KVM: x86: Skip pae_root shadow allocation if tdp
      enabled, 2018-07-25)

(2) A similar report on 'openstack-discuss' list:

      http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-September/009770.html
      -- "issues creating a second vm with numa affinity"

(3) And the following libvirt commits (and an old, related, libvirt bug):

      - https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1010885#c2
        -- "kvm_init_vcpu failed: Cannot allocate memory in NUMA"

      - https://libvirt.org/git/?p=libvirt.git;a=commit;h=0eaa4716e1
        -- "qemu: Set up EMULATOR thread and cpuset.mems before
        exec()-ing qemu")

      - https://libvirt.org/git/?p=libvirt.git;a=commit;h=7e72ac7878
        -- "qemu: leave restricting cpuset.mems after initialization"

Change-Id: I2047f935bdffbc72b066d905b0766bfb1f3cc57a
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
Thanks: Sean Mooney <work@seanmooney.info>

When instance_get_all_uuids_by_hosts was added [1], and tuned up
in [2], some uses of InstanceList.get_by_host() can be replaced
with InstanceList.get_uuids_by_host() because we only need
instance.uuid rather than whole instance object in such scenarios.
In this way, we can reduce many joins in db, and improve
query performance.

commit_message:
Reduce uses of InstanceList.get_by_host().

When instance_get_all_uuids_by_hosts was added [1], and tuned up
in [2], some uses of InstanceList.get_by_host() can be replaced
with InstanceList.get_uuids_by_host() because we only need
instance.uuid rather than whole instance object in such scenarios.
In this way, we can reduce many joins in db, and improve
query performance.

[1] If92fe8b75d20a738f37e2a74c52c59bfc699a74f
[2] Ib538ab070d73b06ddeb9fea3af149304e40952ec
Signed-off-by: Fan Zhang <zh.f@outlook.com>

Change-Id: I849f9cd9c8facdbefb247861414c8ae392b16c1a

messages: [{'account_id': 935, 'date': '2020-05-11 11:50:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 20870, 'date': '2020-05-11 12:49:43.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2\n\nLGTM'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2020-05-11 12:49:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 13686, 'date': '2020-05-11 12:50:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-11 11:50:02.000000000', 'message': 'Set sane min pg size with autoscaler

Resync charmhelpers to pickup behavioural changes in
autoscaler configuration for pools.

This ensures that pools that have a calculated pg size
less than the default of 32 get a min size set to match
the calculated pg size avoiding instance scale-up to
32 pgs.

This avoids overloading of the max pgs per osd limit
in smaller test clusters.

Change-Id: Ic34d029dae9c67dbba3e2e502d7c9ac4576fcfa5
Closes-Bug: 1872748
'}]
commit_message:
Set sane min pg size with autoscaler

Resync charmhelpers to pickup behavioural changes in
autoscaler configuration for pools.

This ensures that pools that have a calculated pg size
less than the default of 32 get a min size set to match
the calculated pg size avoiding instance scale-up to
32 pgs.

This avoids overloading of the max pgs per osd limit
in smaller test clusters.

Change-Id: Ic34d029dae9c67dbba3e2e502d7c9ac4576fcfa5
Closes-Bug: 1872748

In Train kolla switched to Python 3 in Debian and Ubuntu source images.
For services running under httpd with mod_wsgi, they should install
libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3 rather than libapache2-mod-wsgi. This was done
for most images, but cyborg and monasca were omitted.  This change fixes
that.

Closes-Bug: #1873421
(cherry picked from commit f5d31da12fa66cedfc2e270b8cd3be8e2bb9254b)
'}]
commit_message:
Use Python 3 for mod_wsgi in cyborg and monasca on Debian/Ubuntu

In Train kolla switched to Python 3 in Debian and Ubuntu source images.
For services running under httpd with mod_wsgi, they should install
libapache2-mod-wsgi-py3 rather than libapache2-mod-wsgi. This was done
for most images, but cyborg and monasca were omitted.  This change fixes
that.

Change-Id: I25cfa62dbf20490685617b4a4185bf95ab91725e
Closes-Bug: #1873421
(cherry picked from commit f5d31da12fa66cedfc2e270b8cd3be8e2bb9254b)

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Remove babel.cfg, this is not needed here at all
- Update requirements, no need for python_version anymore
- Switch to using sphinx-build
- Use newer openstackdocstheme and Sphinx versions
- Cleanup */source/conf.py to remove now obsolete content.
- Remove install_command from tox.ini, the default is fine
- Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE, UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is obsolete

Change-Id: Ie04a0c0c5270ae49097c3784bac3467c8e43acca

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ia3f8a3aafe3357a574c84042da40da7f0f333fb6
'}]
commit_message:
Update TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: Ia3f8a3aafe3357a574c84042da40da7f0f333fb6

messages:
[{'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2020-05-08 07:42:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 26622, 'date': '2020-05-08 07:50:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

For rechecking only on the Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI, add a review comment with run-Cloudbase Neutron Hyper-V CI

- neutron http://cloudbase-ci.com/neutron/726301/1 : FAILURE in 7m 42s'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2020-05-11 08:27:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-08 07:42:07.000000000', 'message': "Router synch shouldn't return unrelated routers

[0] introduced the concept of connected routers: routers that are
connected to the same subnets. When a L3 agent is synching a router
with connected routers, the data of the entire set should be returned
to the agent by the Neutron server.

However, if an agent tries to synch a router with
no connected routers when the same agent has other routers that are
connected among them, the Neutron server returns the former and the
latter. For details of how this bug can manifest itself, please see [1].

This change prevents this situation: only the synched router is
returned.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/597567
[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1838449/comments/15

Change-Id: Ibbf35d0f4a0bf9281f0bc8c411e8527eed75361d
Closes-Bug: #1838449
(cherry picked from commit 48ea7da6c52ee14f0e9cc244fbc834283a8e74a7)
"}]
commit_message:
Router synch shouldn't return unrelated routers

[0] introduced the concept of connected routers: routers that are
connected to the same subnets. When a L3 agent is synching a router
with connected routers, the data of the entire set should be returned
to the agent by the Neutron server.

However, if an agent tries to synch a router with
no connected routers when the same agent has other routers that are
connected among them, the Neutron server returns the former and the
latter. For details of how this bug can manifest itself, please see [1].

This change prevents this situation: only the synched router is
returned.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/597567
[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1838449/comments/15

Change-Id: Ibbf35d0f4a0bf9281f0bc8c411e8527eed75361d
Closes-Bug: #1838449
(cherry picked from commit 48ea7da6c52ee14f0e9cc244fbc834283a8e74a7)

commit_message:
Convert jobs to dib

Remove the value of IRONIC_RAMDISK_TYPE when present to make
the base job and all children take the type from ironic-base
which now is set to use the dib image.

Change-Id: I59f00c0b135f209ca6258efe9c3e3eb722fff4cb

commit_message:
Silence debug messages from oslo_messaging

We already silence the "oslo.messaging" prefix, but the library
also uses "oslo_messsaging" in some cases.

Change-Id: Ifa9743c39bbd1424fbb07e2b65f409c9d7ca826a
(cherry picked from commit aa43322544d70994ba94c63c0de46a1b80234467)

[{'created': '2020-05-11 10:59:27.000000000', 'message': 'Check for peer series upgrade in pause and status

Check whether peers have sent series upgrade notifications before
pausing a unit. If notifications have been sent then HA services
will have been shutdown and pausing will fail.

Similarly, if series upgrade notifications have been sent then

commit_message:
Check for peer series upgrade in pause and status

Check whether peers have sent series upgrade notifications before
pausing a unit. If notifications have been sent then HA services
will have been shutdown and pausing will fail.

Similarly, if series upgrade notifications have been sent then
do not try and issue crm commands when assessing status.

Change-Id: I4de0ffe5d5e24578db614c2e8640ebd32b8cd469
Closes-Bug: #1877937

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-05 22:44:47.000000000', 'message': 'Add stable branch jobs on the plugins master gate

Supported stable branches in maintenance state
(stein, train, ussuri) use the Tempest and plugins master
version for their testing. To make sure master version (new
tests or any changes) is compatible with stable branch testing,
we need to add the stable branches job on the plugins master gate.
Tempest and many other plugins are already testing the stable
branches in same way[1].

Ussuri onwards, Tempest or plugins are py3 only, so we are
running only python3 version of stable jobs

Tempest plugins guide for stable branch testing:
- https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/stable_branch_testing_policy.html

 [1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/src/commit/e8f1876aa6772077f85f380677b30251c2454505/.zuul.yaml#L646

Change-Id: If608c6af470f8a1645750e779392856b3a3d29db

commit_message:
Add stable branch jobs on the plugins master gate

Supported stable branches in maintenance state
(stein, train, ussuri) use the Tempest and plugins master
version for their testing. To make sure master version (new
tests or any changes) is compatible with stable branch testing,
we need to add the stable branches job on the plugins master gate.
Tempest and many other plugins are already testing the stable
branches in same way[1].

Ussuri onwards, Tempest or plugins are py3 only, so we are
running only python3 version of stable jobs

Tempest plugins guide for stable branch testing:
- https://docs.openstack.org/tempest/latest/stable_branch_testing_policy.html

 [1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/src/commit/e8f1876aa6772077f85f380677b30251c2454505/.zuul.yaml#L646
 

Change-Id: If608c6af470f8a1645750e779392856b3a3d29db

commit_message:
Remove CI for fedora-latest

The fedora-latest build is broken on master and stable branches. OSA
do not support depoyment on Fedora so this job is removed to allow
other code to merge.

Change-Id: Iee174f76d732941ef97b75612c1420c3dee335f3
(cherry picked from commit cb7ace691883a6a7bef84b2c3652c0f26be91feb)

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove setup.* files, these are not needed for this repo
- Cleanup */source/conf.py to remove now obsolete content.
- Remove install_command from tox.ini, the default is fine,
  move constraints into deps, cleanup a bit
- Enable warnings for docs building
- Correct ansible search/match tests for ansible 2.9

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/726645
Change-Id: Ia5aaa8f41172fe200d1d7ce0c7b6f26f7834e38a

subject: Speed up sdist build
messages: [{'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-05-10 22:45:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-05-11 09:27:02.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-05-11 10:41:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-10 22:45:54.000000000', 'message': "Speed up sdist build

We have a couple validations that need to build an sdist now. But once
it has been built in our temporary pristine clone, we don't need to
build it again. Because we create a clean clone, we also don't need to
worry about any stale dist builds. This adds a check to the sdist build
logic to recognize if an sdist has already been built and skip it.

There are also a few extra steps in the build process that are not
needed for our purposes. The biggest is the new(ish) pbr behavior of
building all release notes in the git tree if reno is present. This adds
an environment variable flag to tell pbr not to do that. While we're at
it, we don't need AUTHORS or CHANGELOG created either, so set the flags
telling pbr to skip those as well.

Change-Id: I15be9a12ff6684729980c40afae9625a8b8e550a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
"}]
commit_message:
Speed up sdist build

We have a couple validations that need to build an sdist now. But once
it has been built in our temporary pristine clone, we don't need to
build it again. Because we create a clean clone, we also don't need to
worry about any stale dist builds. This adds a check to the sdist build
logic to recognize if an sdist has already been built and skip it.

There are also a few extra steps in the build process that are not
needed for our purposes. The biggest is the new(ish) pbr behavior of
building all release notes in the git tree if reno is present. This adds
an environment variable flag to tell pbr not to do that. While we're at
it, we don't need AUTHORS or CHANGELOG created either, so set the flags
telling pbr to skip those as well.

Change-Id: I15be9a12ff6684729980c40afae9625a8b8e550a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

[{'created': '2020-05-10 22:45:54.000000000', 'message': 'Install wheel in validate venv

During validation we need to build a bdist_wheel which is only available
as an extension when wheel is present in the environment. This adds
wheel and makes sure all requirements are installed for the validation
job.

Change-Id: Ied3b1ff4accf66e358cec4b209f4d3a65ae88d26

commit_message:
Install wheel in validate venv

During validation we need to build a bdist_wheel which is only available
as an extension when wheel is present in the environment. This adds
wheel and makes sure all requirements are installed for the validation
job.

Change-Id: Ied3b1ff4accf66e358cec4b209f4d3a65ae88d26
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Increase validate job timeout to 3 hours

This can take a long time now with doing the final release tag
validation when all deliverables are included in one patch. Part of the
delay appears to be that pbr was updated to build release notes if reno
is present. We may look for other ways to optimize the validation jobs
to speed things up, but for now we can just make sure we have a very
large window.

Change-Id: I248968bca9a90a7b06d4d6dd0644c50d926e5f45
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fix role to work with Jinja 2.7

By default Centos is shipped with Jinja 2.7.2 which do not have `in`
test. So we replace that logic with rejecting absent packages
and suggest that the rest of statuses are valid for
package installation.

Change-Id: Ibeb3aba5cccddc1af1f968c57bdc0be75e7f22d9
(cherry picked from commit e1d8ec221126a80b029bbd371b422e5ffe85fadd)

subject: Update add_reviewers to add to all open reviews
messages: [{'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-05-09 12:15:15.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2020-05-11 09:24:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 28522, 'date': '2020-05-11 10:35:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-09 12:15:15.000000000', 'message': 'Update add_reviewers to add to all open reviews

This updates the script to not require a specific topic to make it
easier to automate a job that periodically makes sure all open reviews
have had the PTL and liaison added.

Also refactored the adding of teams because bash array handling can be a
bit wonky sometimes and not always append values. This makes sure no
teams are skipped.

This is slightly less optimized for large reviews like the final series
release since it loops through teams based on the deliverable files. As
a slight optimization, it will skip a team if it was the same team as
the last deliverable file. It just might be possible that the same team
will be processed multiple times if their deliverable files are not in
alphabetical order, but there is no harm in that other than taking
slightly longer to complete.

Change-Id: I9a9194ea276aa0120aef21a321f48a93419fb848
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Update add_reviewers to add to all open reviews

This updates the script to not require a specific topic to make it
easier to automate a job that periodically makes sure all open reviews
have had the PTL and liaison added.

Also refactored the adding of teams because bash array handling can be a
bit wonky sometimes and not always append values. This makes sure no
teams are skipped.

This is slightly less optimized for large reviews like the final series
release since it loops through teams based on the deliverable files. As
a slight optimization, it will skip a team if it was the same team as
the last deliverable file. It just might be possible that the same team
will be processed multiple times if their deliverable files are not in
alphabetical order, but there is no harm in that other than taking
slightly longer to complete.

Change-Id: I9a9194ea276aa0120aef21a321f48a93419fb848
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Ansible 'version' is a test not a filter.

The previously used syntax worked on ansible < 2.9, but now it is
invalid and fails.

Change-Id: Ic8fc9327e6814d310d862ab3ce8d323f30faa359

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-06 15:35:19.000000000', 'message': 'logstash: add cisco ios/nexus syslog parsing to pipeline

Adds parsing for Cisco NXOS/IOS syslog format, along with the
RFC5424 variant some devices can use. Messages which match these
patterns are fingerprinted based upon the message and host to
de-duplicate them when storing in elasticsearch.

Change-Id: I42fd441913d2095997c3493c37515362a5d732fc
'}]
commit_message:
logstash: add cisco ios/nexus syslog parsing to pipeline

Adds parsing for Cisco NXOS/IOS syslog format, along with the
RFC5424 variant some devices can use. Messages which match these
patterns are fingerprinted based upon the message and host to
de-duplicate them when storing in elasticsearch.

Change-Id: I42fd441913d2095997c3493c37515362a5d732fc

This seems similar in concept to I8ce65e1d357d15e8ed8995ad1dcaea02bbd1986f ... i think there is argument there to move to -kvm images too.

I'm a little worried it might drop some storage driver somebody relies on, but I think the general idea that we make -minimal smaller for what i'd see as the most common case of virtualized images, and add things back in if required for corner cases is worth taking."}, {'account_id': 25402, 'date': '2019-09-03 15:51:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-09-06 05:36:05.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 7118, 'date': '2019-09-06 05:36:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

on reflection i just thought this should have a release note in case it breaks anyone and they look to see what's going on.  LGTM"}, {'account_id': 17799, 'date': '2019-10-13 01:13:50.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Note for anyone trying to build bare metal images overriding this back to leave firmware installed.

It will need to be added to a custom element's package-installs.yaml using a phase override, otherwise it will be missing from the image.

linux-firmware:
  phase: post-install.d"}, {'account_id': 29100, 'date': '2020-03-05 18:42:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Thanks Logan for the tip. I tried building a custom IPA image (using ironic-disk-image-builder), and with this package missing, I did not have firmware for my NICs (Broadcom NetXtreme II 10Gb, using bnx2x firmware). Perhaps this is more of an issue for the ironic-python-agent ramdisk builds, as they target bare metal, but it was unexpected.'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2020-05-11 09:54:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Thanks for the hints folks, I'm updating IPA-builder: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/726769/"}]

firmwares) packages account for approx. 289 M install size on a F30

commit_message:
Uninstall linux-firmware and linux-firmware-whence

linux-firmware and linux-firmware-whence (meta package for mostly iwl
firmwares) packages account for approx. 289 M install size on a F30
system, and linux-firmware for approx. 176 M on CentOS 7. Users needing
these firmwares are eventually baremetal users and are not looking for a
very minimal operating system base install like virtual image users are.
Thus, a non-minimal OS element is better suited for them. Alternatively,
it could be later considered a dedicated firmware element.

This is inline with I8ce65e1d357d15e8ed8995ad1dcaea02bbd1986f.

Change-Id: If104fc3c1e9349b8d501a2351fff1ab4c0dbc6a4

commit_message:
Enable mod_wsgi in Nova API container

This patch modifies the Dockerfile for the Nova API so that
the 'root' user executes the container setup scripts.
This enables the container httpd configuration script to execute.

Change-Id: I374af00a374346840c12777a530d39768b28c908
Partially-Implements: blueprint add-ssl-internal-network
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/725962

commit_message:
Remove kolla-ceph

Kolla-Ansible Ceph deployment mechanism has been deprecated in Train [1].

This change removes the Ansible code and associated CI jobs.

[1]: https://review.opendev.org/669214

Change-Id: Ie2167f02ad2f525d3b0f553e2c047516acf55bc2

commit_message:
Ensure OAuth1 authorized roles are respected

Without this patch, when an OAuth1 request token is authorized with a
limited set of roles, the roles for the access token are ignored when
the user uses it to request a keystone token. This means that user of an
access token can use it to escallate their role assignments beyond what
was authorized by the creator. This patch fixes the issue by ensuring
the token model accounts for an OAuth1-scoped token and correctly
populating the roles for it.

Change-Id: I02f9836fbd4d7e629653977fc341476cfd89859e
Closes-bug: #1873290
(cherry picked from commit 6c73690f779a42a5c62914b6bc37f0ac2f41a3e3)
(cherry picked from commit ba89d27793c2d3a26ad95642660fa9bd820ed3be)
(cherry picked from commit 5ff52dbaa2082991d229d8557a8e4b65256d6c53)

commit_message:
Make nova perms consistent between applications

Nova cells support introduced a slight regression that triggers
odd behaviour when we tried switching to Apache (httpd) [1].
Bootstrap no longer applied permissions recursively to all log
files, creating a discrepancy between normal and bootstrap runs
and also Nova and other services such as Cinder (regarding
bootstrap logging).

This patch fixes it.

Backport to Train.

Not creating reno nor a bug record because it does not affect
any current standard usage in any currently known way.

Note this only really hides (standardizes?) the global issue that
we don't control file permissions on newly created files too well.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/724793

Change-Id: I35e9924ccede5edd2e1307043379aba944725143
Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/724793

commit_message:
Add timeout and retries to JSON RPC client

The necessary options are already in keystoneauth, but have empty
defaults. This patch changes timeout to 15 and adds 2 retries by default.

Change-Id: Idf8cfa54b77be6f5127d2c9d587a427aa0898802

Remove bridge-utils/brctl usage

required in Neutron for several years

[{'created': '2020-05-04 06:40:53.000000000', 'message': 'Switch to new grenade job name

The integrated gate templates has switched to the new grenade name
(grenade-py3 -> grenade). This repo uses an integrated gate template
but also listed the job for irrelevant files an extra entry.

Rename the job following the template change to avoid duplicate
grenade runs.

Details:
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014602.html

Change-Id: I0a981738034468bc8e0ef2944cb8b2b7a68e3851
'}]
commit_message:
Switch to new grenade job name

The integrated gate templates has switched to the new grenade name
(grenade-py3 -> grenade). This repo uses an integrated gate template
but also listed the job for irrelevant files an extra entry.

Rename the job following the template change to avoid duplicate
grenade runs.

Details:
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2020-May/014602.html

Change-Id: I0a981738034468bc8e0ef2944cb8b2b7a68e3851

commit_message:
Validate resource access when creating loadbalancer or member

* Make sure the user has access to the subnet in the request for
  creating or updating pool member.
* Make sure the user has access to port or subnet or network for
  creating load balancer

Story: 2007531
Task: 39339

Change-Id: I479019a911b5a1acfc1951d1cbbc2a351089cb4d
(cherry picked from commit a33d42fa59ada38dd5a5d3114a9a83f03a30d0b2)

commit_message:
Use unittest.mock instead of third party mock

Now that we no longer support py27, we can use the standard library
unittest.mock module instead of the third party mock lib.

Change-Id: I1cffb9710f9e6b9b8b1f5e658d5af8668f3fca4c
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-11 03:07:00.000000000', 'message': "Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Remove babel.cfg, this is not needed here at all
- Update requirements, no need for python_version anymore
- Switch to using sphinx-build
- Use newer openstackdocstheme and Sphinx versions
- Remove install_command from tox.ini, the default is fine
- Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE, UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is obsolete

Change-Id: I57d447e034c088c83fdd5fb8854dbd9826a200a8
"}]
commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg
- Remove babel.cfg, this is not needed here at all
- Update requirements, no need for python_version anymore
- Switch to using sphinx-build
- Use newer openstackdocstheme and Sphinx versions
- Remove install_command from tox.ini, the default is fine
- Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE, UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is obsolete

Change-Id: I57d447e034c088c83fdd5fb8854dbd9826a200a8

Congratulations, you've proposed your first change in OpenDev.

Your submission will now be tested automatically by Zuul, our gatekeeper,
and reviewed by other friendly developers. They will give you feedback and
may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches often take days (and sometimes weeks) to get reviewed, so be
patient. Don't hesitate to ask for help, and answer questions about your
work promptly if you can. The more you get to know reviewers and get to be
known by them, the smoother the review and approval process will become. The
fastest way to accomplish this is by reviewing other proposed changes
yourself: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for participating in OpenDev, we look forward to seeing you
around.

commit_message:
Fix healthmanager not update amphora health when LB disable

When disable a loadbalancer have listener, the Heath Manager not update
amphora heath make it keep failover after heartbeat_timeout end time

Story: 2007587
Task: 39521

subject: Fix: API returns 503 if one of the store is mis-configured
messages:
[{'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-04-24 15:40:06.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-04-24 15:40:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 18002, 'date': '2020-04-24 16:57:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

This fixed my bug. Thank you Abhishek

If I misconfigure my glance-api.conf with an incorrect rbd_store_user for one of my store then that store does not work as expected. The difference is that with this patch the other stores DO work but without this patch, all queries to glance fail with a 50x error. 

With this patch in place I am still able to query glance and I just see the following message in my logs:

2020-04-24 16:53:52.696 6 WARNING glance_store.driver [-] Failed to configure store correctly: Store %(store_name)s could not be configured correctly. Reason: %(reason)s Disabling add method.: glance_store.exceptions.BadStoreConfiguration: Store %(store_name)s could not be configured correctly. Reason: %(reason)s'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-04-27 06:47:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-04-27 06:48:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

 > If I misconfigure my glance-api.conf with an incorrect
 > rbd_store_user for one of my store then that store does not work as

 > DO work but without this patch, all queries to glance fail with a

 > 
 > 2020-04-24 16:53:52.696 6 WARNING glance_store.driver [-] Failed to

 > configured correctly. Reason: %(reason)s Disabling add method.:
 > glance_store.exceptions.BadStoreConfiguration: Store %(store_name)s
 > could not be configured correctly. Reason: %(reason)s

Thank you John for confirming, fixed the warning message in new PS.'}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2020-05-07 03:48:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Review-Priority+1'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2020-05-07 12:17:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2

[{'created': '2020-04-24 15:40:06.000000000', 'message': '[DNM] Fix single store failure in multiple stores

Change-Id: I685a0ecbfba7cf7dbce3fd2eb84f97bd8ffbfcf3
'}, {'created': '2020-04-27 06:47:31.000000000', 'message': 'Fix: API returns 503 if one of the store is mis-configured

If user mis-configures one of the multiple stores defined in glance-api
configuratio file, then service returns 503 for all API requests.

Made provision to exclude faulty store and resume service normally
to function wiht other configured stores.

Closes-Bug: #1875281
Change-Id: I685a0ecbfba7cf7dbce3fd2eb84f97bd8ffbfcf3
'}]
commit_message:
Fix: API returns 503 if one of the store is mis-configured

If user mis-configures one of the multiple stores defined in glance-api
configuratio file, then service returns 503 for all API requests.

Made provision to exclude faulty store and resume service normally
to function wiht other configured stores.

Closes-Bug: #1875281
Change-Id: I685a0ecbfba7cf7dbce3fd2eb84f97bd8ffbfcf3

Do we face some errors with this trailing slash?'}, {'account_id': 26721, 'date': '2020-05-11 04:07:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

yes, we had. 
For example, with the trailing slash, the gnocchi query url will become http://gnocchi_service_url//v1/search/resource/instance and the return is not correct.'}, {'account_id': 14107, 'date': '2020-05-11 05:50:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

commit_message:
Fix the endpoint url trailing slash issue

Keystone catalog url could be with or without the trailing slash.
Removing it when get the endpoint.

Change-Id: I55bbfb5823957ff50d9a588c9cc1a9faebecffff

commit_message:
Add nova-compute configuration for hwoffload

Ensure that the nova-compute charm is configured for PCI
passthrough of offloaded network devices via the
pci-passthrough-whitelist configuration option.

Change-Id: I23fea95b1f6646f420746fddf4fb4b63ba9c3c86

revisions:
[{'created': '2020-05-06 15:17:45.000000000', 'message': "Fix security issues with EC2 credentials

This change addresses several issues in the creation and use of EC2/S3
credentials with keystone tokens.

1. Disable altering credential owner attributes or metadata

Without this patch, an authenticated user can create an EC2 credential
for themself for a project they have a role on, then update the
credential to target a user and project completely unrelated to them. In
the worst case, this could be the admin user and a project the admin
user has a role assignment on. A token granted for an altered credential
like this would allow the user to masquerade as the victim user. This
patch ensures that when updating a credential, the new form of the
credential is one the acting user has access to: if the system admin
user is changing the credential, the new user ID or project ID could be
anything, but regular users may only change the credential to be one
that they still own.

Relatedly, when a user uses an application credential or a trust to
create an EC2 credential, keystone automatically adds the trust ID or
application credential ID as metadata in the EC2 access blob so that it
knows how the token can be scoped when it is used. Without this patch, a
user who has created a credential in this way can update the access blob
to remove or alter this metadata and escalate their privileges to be
fully authorized for the trustor's, application credential creator's, or
OAuth1 access token authorizor's privileges on the project. This patch
fixes the issue by simply disallowing updates to keystone-controlled
metadata in the credential.

2. Respect token roles when creating EC2 credentials

Without this patch, a trustee, an application credential user, or an
OAuth1 access token holder could create an EC2 credential or an
application credential using any roles the trustor, application
credential creator, or access token authorizor had on the project,
regardless of whether the creator had delegated only a limited subset of
roles. This was because the trust_id attribute of the EC2 access blob
was ignored, and no metadata for the application credential or access
token was recorded either. This change ensures that the access
delegation resource is recorded in the metadata of the EC2 credential
when created and passed to the token provider when used for
authentication so that the token provider can look up the correct roles
for the request.

Conflicts (six removal in  e2d83ae9, pep8 fixes in e2d83ae9, test helper
in 52da4d0e12):
      keystone/api/credentials.py
      keystone/tests/unit/test_v3_application_credential.py
      keystone/tests/unit/test_v3_credential.py

Change-Id: I39d0d705839fbe31ac518ac9a82959e108cb7c1d
Closes-bug: #1872733
Closes-bug: #1872755
Closes-bug: #1872735
(cherry picked from commit 37e9907a176dad6843819b1bec4946c3aecc4548)
(cherry picked from commit 2f2736ebb267c757ad77fcf25ee0aaeefab2a09d)

Conflicts (six removal in  e2d83ae9, pep8 fixes in e2d83ae9, test helper
in 52da4d0e12):
      keystone/api/credentials.py
      keystone/tests/unit/test_v3_application_credential.py
      keystone/tests/unit/test_v3_credential.py

Depends-on: https://review.opendev.org/726526

commit_message:
Fix security issues with EC2 credentials

This change addresses several issues in the creation and use of EC2/S3
credentials with keystone tokens.

1. Disable altering credential owner attributes or metadata

Without this patch, an authenticated user can create an EC2 credential
for themself for a project they have a role on, then update the
credential to target a user and project completely unrelated to them. In
the worst case, this could be the admin user and a project the admin
user has a role assignment on. A token granted for an altered credential
like this would allow the user to masquerade as the victim user. This
patch ensures that when updating a credential, the new form of the
credential is one the acting user has access to: if the system admin
user is changing the credential, the new user ID or project ID could be
anything, but regular users may only change the credential to be one
that they still own.

Relatedly, when a user uses an application credential or a trust to
create an EC2 credential, keystone automatically adds the trust ID or
application credential ID as metadata in the EC2 access blob so that it
knows how the token can be scoped when it is used. Without this patch, a
user who has created a credential in this way can update the access blob
to remove or alter this metadata and escalate their privileges to be
fully authorized for the trustor's, application credential creator's, or
OAuth1 access token authorizor's privileges on the project. This patch
fixes the issue by simply disallowing updates to keystone-controlled
metadata in the credential.

2. Respect token roles when creating EC2 credentials

Without this patch, a trustee, an application credential user, or an
OAuth1 access token holder could create an EC2 credential or an
application credential using any roles the trustor, application
credential creator, or access token authorizor had on the project,
regardless of whether the creator had delegated only a limited subset of
roles. This was because the trust_id attribute of the EC2 access blob
was ignored, and no metadata for the application credential or access
token was recorded either. This change ensures that the access
delegation resource is recorded in the metadata of the EC2 credential
when created and passed to the token provider when used for
authentication so that the token provider can look up the correct roles
for the request.

Conflicts (six removal in  e2d83ae9, pep8 fixes in e2d83ae9, test helper
in 52da4d0e12):
      keystone/api/credentials.py

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

This repo is now testing only with Python 3, so let's make
a few cleanups:
- Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
- Add requires on python >= 3.6 to setup.cfg so that pypi and pip
  know about the requirement
- Update classifiers
- Use newer openstackdocstheme and Sphinx versions
- Build docs, don't publish yet

Change-Id: I2de4e1dbac061002940f80b2cf129dc343343a0d

commit_message:
Cleanup py27 support

Make a few cleanups:
- Remove python 2.7 stanza from setup.py
- Remove obsolete sections from setup.cfg:
  * Wheel is not needed for python 3 only repo
  * Some other sections are obsolete
- Update classifiers
- Update requirements, no need for python_version anymore

Change-Id: I7d14a347fd25822736835127e67d37d57859e356

commit_message:
Ignore `self` property if passed on image create

The `self` property is returned from an `image show` but is not viable
in an `image create`, breaking programmatic cloning of images that was
possible previously (before the switch to SDK from glanceclient).
This breaks some existing operator workflows, which we should try to not
do.

Change-Id: I2f6f022edc7f2d2f4f51b72fd3e57addae2f6e9a

commit_message:
Show owner_id AND owner as properties

This is to retain compatibility with the original glanceclient / OSC
`image show` operations. Before switching to using this SDK Image class,
the owner_id would show as a property AND owner would appear as a
property and be translated to a base attribute. Without this change,
owner remains as a property and owner_id does not appear at all.

Change-Id: Ib6866a6e702814238186cfc206de75c112e463d0
